title: Introduction of Xinjiang
description: Xinjiang, officially the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region (XUAR), is an autonomous region of the People's Republic of China, located in the northwest of the country. Being the largest province-level division of China and the 8th largest country subdivision in the world, Xinjiang spans over 1.6 million km2 (640,000 square miles). The Aksai Chin region, administered by China mostly as part of Xinjiang's Hotan Prefecture, is claimed by India. Xinjiang borders the countries of Mongolia (Bayan-Ã–lgii, Khovd and Govi-Altai Provinces), Russia (Altai Republic), Kazakhstan (East Kazakhstan and Almaty Provinces), Kyrgyzstan (Issyk Kul, Naryn and Osh Regions), Tajikistan (Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Region), and Afghanistan (Badakhshan). The rugged Karakoram, Kunlun and Tian Shan mountain ranges occupy much of Xinjiang's borders, as well as its western and southern regions. Xinjiang also borders the Tibet Autonomous Region and the provinces of Gansu and Qinghai. The most well-known route of the historical Silk Road ran through the territory from the east to its northwestern border.

title: Xinjiang's Economy
description: Xinjiang has traditionally been an agricultural region, but is also rich in minerals and oil. Nominal GDP was about 932.4 billion RMB (US$140 billion) as of 2015 with an average annual increase of 10.4% for the past four years, due to discovery of the abundant reserves of coal, oil, gas as well as the China Western Development policy introduced by the State Council to boost economic development in Western China. Its per capita GDP for 2009 was 19,798 RMB (US$2,898), with a growth rate of 1.7%. Southern Xinjiang, with 95% non-Han population, has an average per capita income half that of Xinjiang as a whole.

title: Dissolution of Bingtuan?
description: Bingtuan has played important role in the governing of Xinjiang. It takes care of both internal and external security -  separatist groups and infiltrators are always major concerns since the first days of China governance. It also plays the role of merging the culture and economical gap between Xinjiang and the eastern part of China: intellectuals and workers immigrated from eastern China brings industrialization and modernization to this northwestern province. Even Bingtuan is mostly self-sufficient on economy, the poor nature conditions in Xinjiang prevents Bingtuan to produce more. Now that the state of economy is not looking good all over the country, some argues for the dissolution of Bingtuan so its members can join the development of more prosperous areas at a higher efficiency.

option.text: Finally we get rid of the economical burden!

title: Bingtuan members returning to the east
description: After the dissolution of Bingtuan, those members who came from cities such as Shanghai when Bingtuan was first founded have now returned to their home. This causes a sharp decrease of educated workers and Han ethnics in Xinjiang.

title: Restoration of Bingtuan?
description: Recent unrest and border tensions brings a voice calling for the restoration of Bingtuan rise to surface in Beijing. Most agree it is the best way to keep possible subversive activities at bay, while the size and urgency of the restoration is not yet decided. Still there are some others claiming it would only be another ineffective economical burden.

option.text: Bring it back in full scale immediately!
Only set up a framework, we can fill it up later.

title: New Bingtuan members needed
description: Since the restoration of Bingtuan has begun, we have to find men willing to fight harsh climate and contribute to local development. The question is, where should we focus on recruiting new members?

option.text: We can bring some people from eastern China.

title: Afghanistan War broke out!
description: The USSR just attacked Afghanistan! No doubt there will be refugees fleeing to our border, and the extended border with USSR will cause more infiltration.

option.text: Strengthen border patrol! We can't let the Soviets infiltrate us.
Let Afghanistan refugees come.

title: New design of RMB notes
description: People's Bank of China is preparing for the publish of a new set of RMB banknotes. Traditionally illustrations of workers and farmers will be featured, but all of them is Han people. We can now include some ethnic figures on the banknotes.

option.text: We can describe different ethnic figures on the banknote.

title: Orthography of Uyghur language
description: Uyghur language had been written in several forms. Now is the time to consider orthography of Uyghur language, so our pulications, education and media can teach and use the orthography.

option.text: Follow the Soviet lead! Use the Cyrillic alphabet
Stay in line with traditions. Use the Arabic alphabet

title: USSR infiltrators?
description: Since we chose Cyrillic alphabet for Orthography, an decrease in USSR infiltrators found by our intelligence agency was reported. It could be a whiff in the air, or means some infiltrators have escaped our notice.

option.text: Strengthen border patrol and internal security!

title: Separatists sentiment increasing!
description: Local officials reported that some groups are spreading separatist sentiment by spreading separatist and Pan-Turkism Arabic articles of foreign source. The Arabic orthography makes Pan-Turkism more popular in the masses.

option.text: Put censorship on Arabic and Uyghur publication!

title: Latinization in rural areas?
description: The Latinization of signs and publications is mostly done in urban areas now. Still, much of the rural areas are still using traditional scripts. We can hurry the project so only latinized Uyghur will be needed in the future, or pause the project as some argues it will preserve Uyghur culture.

option.text: We have to done it thoroughly. Leave no gap between cities and countryside!
We should halt this project.

title: Local resistance of Chinese!
description: In the process of substituting Uyghur with Chinese, we meet some resistance. Some local teachers themselves are not fluent with Chinese and general efficiency of society has decreased due to low language difficulties. We may now force this process at the risk of social instability, or take a milder stance at the cost of efficiency.

option.text: Force the issue! There is no turning back.
Use moderate ways, there is no need to hurry.

title: Standardize Uyghur language
description: After the orthography of Uyghur language is completed, we can consider to standardize it as we did to Putonghua. Going for extensive field research will preserve the culture better, but at a higher expense.

option.text: A language is defined by its speakers. We should include as many dialects as possible.
Incorporating all dialects is ineffective and unnecessary. Use city dialects as source is enough.

title: Modernizing Uyghur: Loaned words
description: Most language have loaned words and it is quite necessary as loaned words can express some concepts better. Some languages loan word from all other languages alike, while other languages have the majority of loaned words loaned from a few languages. When it comes to Uyghur language, what policy shall we chose?

option.text: A live language may loan word from any language.
Better to restrict loaned words to those of Chinese source.
To keep a language pure, no loaned words are allowed.

title: An identity for people live in Xinjiang
description: We may strengthen the national identity in our media and education for people live in Xinjiang by referring them to "Chinese Nationals" as a whole or strengthen ethnic identity by seperating them into different groups such as "Uyghurs/Tajiks/Huis". We can be even more radical, claiming all of them are Han, just like "Hui people are only Han who believe in Muslim".

option.text: We are all Chinese citizens. Strengthen the national identity.
People belong to their ethnic group. Strengthen the ethnic identity.
There are no such things as ethnic group in China, only Han with different traditions! Strengthen Han identity.

title: Handling Pan-Turkism
description: Pan-Turkism is somewhat controversial. The culture in Xinjiang, especially the Uyghur language do have some resemblance with Turk culture. However, Pan-Turkism also is the rally flag of several separatism groups. How should we handle it?

option.text: Only recognize the connections between Turk language and Uyghur language.
Turk culture has much resemblance with the culture in Xinjiang, we can promote it.
Pan-Turkism is culture infiltration! We need sinicization to combat it.

title: Education reforms in Xinjiang
description: Previously kids are taught in local language in primary schools and only those who have access to higher education recieve Chinese education. Now we have several plans of reform.

option.text: Chinese should be used as the academic language while other languages will be taught for daily communication.
We should treat all languages as equals in all fields.

title: State owned media in Xinjiang
description: We have several state owned media in Xinjiang. In the past days, their majority audience is Han people, so only Chinese is used. Now more and more locals are enjoying these media, should we created a local language version for them?

option.text: Both Chinese and local language version should be created and broadcasted.
Media faces the masses, only the local language version is needed.
Media is the best way to spread the use of Chinese. Only the Chinese version is enough.

title: Completion of Karakorum highway
description: The completion of Karakorum highway is a milestone for infrastructure construction in Xinjiang. As the saying goes: "Infrastructure is the gate to prosperity"

title: Opening of Khunjerab pass?

option.text: Of course! Opening the pass will encourage economical growth.

title: Further Opening of border passes?
description: The Khunjerab pass has been proven successful in many ways. The surge in cross-border trade and the local economy boom encourage more areas applying for further opening of border passes. How should we reply?

option.text: More opened passes, more trade.

title: Discovery of Tarim petroleum

It would be of great importance since the deposite northeastern petroleum fields are running low and demands of petroleum is increasing. Develop is necessary, but when? Poor infrastructure around the basin brings difficulties in development and some say we shall improve infrastructure first.

option.text: Use improvised roads to cope, we can't afford delays.

title: Infrastructures ready
description: The completion of Lanzhou-Xinjiang Railway brings a surge of economical development in Xinjiang. New roads are built all over the province and the transportation capacity has increased sharply.

option.text: Now we can safely develop the petroleum

title: Completion of Lanzhou-Xinjiang Railway
description: Lanzhou-Xinjiang is one of the most important transportation infrastructure in northwestern China. The days of insufficient transportation capacity are no longer our concern.
